reviewText: The games are somewhat amusing.  They are pretty accurate in picking up your movements.  However, like another reviewer said, the workouts for the trainer do not pick up all of your movements.  From what I have noticed, you have to memorize the moves and then perform them faster than the "instructor" on screen in order to get credit for them.  But don't go too fast, otherwise you'll get "out of sync".  They really need to at least make the game where you can lag anywhere from a quarter to half a second behind the instructor or be a quarter or half a second faster than the instructor in order to get the best results.  Because, lets face it, the Kinect has a minor lag, and we as humans have a minor lag when turning what we see into actions.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This product performs well for people who are already relatively fit and maybe just want to lose a few pounds or add some tone to their body.  However, the sensitivities work poorly (and often not at all) for people who are overweight or obese, and those users will be constantly frustrated.For example, the program does not account for the reality that overweight/obese users will not be able to "lunge" down as much as the coach instructor.  It will also frequently report that the user is "out of sync" (even though you can clearly see the user is dead-on accurate and in-sync).  These are problems a more slender user will not experience.However, this is the product's intention.  It is called "Fitness Evolved", which presumes that you are already quite fit and just want to take it to the next level.  If this describes you, this is a great product.  It features lots of activities, a progressive exercise level, and a variety of exercise types.  You will love this product.But I'm addressing this review to those users who are overweight or obese and were hoping for a way to workout at home and help lose weight.  Those users should save their money!  This will be a disappointing program that only servers to frustrate and annoy you.The overweight person in our household quickly became discouraged by this program and instead works up a terrific sweat, burns significant calories, and has a lot more fun playing Kinect Sports!
summary: Not intended for overweight or obese users

reviewText: This game is everything I had hoped for in motion tracking.It has yoga, and punching, and mini games like hula hoop and tetris like balancing.The imaging technology makes me feel like I am at the airport. It can even sense where heat is higher. You will love this game, a must have for anyone interested in shedding a few pound.
summary: I felt this the next day
Title: N/A

reviewText: Pros:  I like the Tai Chi portions, where the camera analyzed your body position and showed you what you were doing wrong, so you can correct your form.  Without proper form, you don't get the benefits, so that was really good.I did break a sweat during the workouts.  The boxing workout was probably the most fun.Cons:The workouts are too slow-paced for me.  There was too much rest time in between sets, and too much instruction for new moves.  That's just a personal preference.For the squats and sidesteps, it kept telling me to widen my stance - which is not exactly possible.  I was practically leaping across my living room trying to make my sidesteps wide enough.Way too many squats.  The toning portions all seemed to be lower body squats and kicks with an occassional arm swing or punch.  I never unlocked the part with free weights that is shown on the package.Overall:I ended up selling my copy.  I didn't need to hang onto it for the tai chi portion.
Title: N/A

reviewText: So let me preface this review by saying I'm in good shape (completed P90X, Insanity, run about 15 miles a week) and had done the original Yourself!Fitness on the Xbox.  So I'm really no slouch when it comes to at least being somewhat "active".All in all, I've been pleased with the workouts provided.  While they aren't very challenging for me, they still get my heart rate up and some sweat has been produced.  More importantly, the burn in my legs is a lot more with this program than other routines I'm doing.If you've done any working out lately, you will get annoyed with the initial player set-up and when you first go through routines.  This game makes you "learn" all the exercises before you can jump in and go...so yes, I had to do the step touch, jumping jacks, front kick, side kick, squat in sync with the trainer.  Now that's kind of annoying but I understand probably a necessary evil for beginners.My kick boxing routine was about 5 minutes long and did a decent job of getting my heart rate up.  My cardio was about 8 minutes and it also did a good job.  So far today, I've burned just under 300 calories in about 30 minutes of messing around with it.Perhaps the most fun for me was choosing the "skin" of my player on the screen.  Multi-color, starry, black and white, skin tone, dazzling, chrome...so many choices.  Right now I'm on the "fire" skin and I look like the flame character human torch from the Fantastic Four!  Very cool!So all in all, I don't think it will give you very hardcore workout...but it will be a great supplemental workout for my other routines.  Especially the Zen yoga.
summary: Overall not a bad start to fitness on your console.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We got our XBox 360 a year ago and this Christmas we added the Kinect module.  At first, I thought this would mostly be for our kids and for family games.  Then, after some trepidation, I pulled the trigger on Your Shape: Fitness Evolved.  I had heard some of the criticisms about lag and not being able to save your progress, so I was a little skeptical.Turns out, I had no reason to be.  I should disclose that I have been into exercise my whole life.  I have been doing long distance running since I was in high school.  I have belonged to gyms off and on for decades.  I own weights and have a pool to swim in.  We also own an elliptical machine.  But somehow, I have been in a rut.  Even though I work out, I can't seem to get back to my ideal weight.  No matter what I did, I stayed in my comfort zone and never made any gains.Then, this game came along.  After two workouts, I can feel soreness in places I never felt before.  Just using the five pound weights, and putting in less than 1 hour sessions, about 40 minutes, I totally feel sore and know new muscle is forming.  I can't wait to go back and do more.  The Zen zone is very cool for warm up and cool down.  The one on one trainer is like having a real one that would normally cost you big buck at a local gym.  I have yet to get bored, and I haven't unlocked 80 per cent of the modules.  From the very start, there is so much to do.  The more you do, the more options  you unlock and the more fun it gets.  It feels tailored to my exact level of fitness, but never lets me get back into a rut.  I highly recommend it, particularly for anyone who feels like working out has become a chore.Best part is you never have to leave your living room.  The space necessary is not that big a deal.  I just slide our ottoman out of the way and push our sofa back about a foot.  The tracking is great.  No need to skip working out because it's winter, or you have kids you must supervise.  After kids go to bed, now I break out Your Shape and I'm good to go.  My wife loves it, too.  I'll be getting those extra modules once we've conquered all that is included.  I love the cardio boxing, too.
summary: Best Work Out I've Had In a Long, Long Time

reviewText: I had high hopes for this game seeing as how the rest of the kinect games were using a lot of body motions and positions.Also seeing as how a lot of the sports and other games used fun as a way to get people moving I hoped this game would as well.WRONG. summary: Fitness for those who never went to the gym
Title: N/A

reviewText: The interface - visuals, animations, etc. - is attractive, but it has problems.For example, the demonstration videos show both sides of an exercise and you're unable to skip this. The load times between exercises or sessions are sometimes too long.There are other problems. For example, in the boxing game where you hit the cubes, sometimes the green cubes appear on top of your blue image just after the last set begins to crumble away. This makes it hard to see, and you sometimes miss them. This could have easily been caught in testing.The selection and confirmation user interface is also inferior to Dance Central's, which is more intuitive. Here you're sometimes trying to poke your hand right in between two other buttons which cycle the selections up and down in order to hit the button you want. It looks nice but is hard to navigate.Also when you want to update your fitness objectives, you have to re-take the fitness quiz and cannot skip the basic tutorial, which you to see all over again. This is a waste of time and is poorly designed workflow.There are not that many games, just four; it would've been nice to have more. The most fun game is boxing/kicking the blocks; the others are just meh.The cardio boxing and tai chi sessions are all right, and the personalized workout is OK, with the issues mentioned above. The squats and such will have you working out, i.e. you'll feel it, although each block (e.g. squats) seems kind of short, and sometimes it will think you are out of rhythm and not score you properly. At least, I though I was in rhythm :) The first issue may be related to the age you input; perhaps if I had input 20, it may have given me more repetitions.It's a good-looking title which mostly works, isn't a standout, and could have been much better. We'll probably try The Biggest Loser title sometime, and this title works with Kinect Sports to give you variety in a workout - Kinect Sports can also have you huffing and puffing with the boxing, table tennis and other minigames, and beach volleyball.
summary: Poor interface design and limited activities
Title: N/A

reviewText: Have had no problems with program recognizing my moves. At 63 years old, have lost some of my cat-like moves and reflexes, but if I do it right and in the right rhythm, it will count. If I don't, it doesn't count and the program fitness queen voice corrects me in a pleasant but directive tone. Before settling on a regular routine, I dinked around with the different offerings. I finally settled on and found a 14 minute routine I do twice, followed by a five minute cardio routine I do four times for an average of 420-430 calories per workout in just under 50 minutes. It's classic "You get out of it what you put into it". Only thing it doesn't do is throw me a towel and yell "Hit the showers Kimble" when done...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am somebody who has always wanted to work out and likes the feeling I get from the rewards a daily workout brings, including having more energy and feeling stronger and more fit. But the problem is, with my incredibly busy schedule and tendency to get bored very easily it has been really difficult to find a program that I could live with. I have tried MANY different things from gym memberships (finding time to go was a hassle, and I HATED changing in the locker room), to excersize equipment in my living room (repetitive and boring), to other fitness games including Wii Fit, My Fitness Coach, and EA Sports Active for the Wii (did not like the Wii controls one bit and gave up). But with Your Shape, I actually ENJOY working out for the first time in my life. The personal training routines are as pleasant as I've ever experienced in excersize and the gym games and fitness classes are downright fun. I also have a knee condition that makes it hard to do certain excersizes (I had problems with EA Sports Active) but I'm not having any problems playing Your Shape. There is a ton of variety of different training regimines to choose from, in addition to fun gym games and classes so it never gets boring. I usually do a training session followed by a class, game, or both. There are workouts here for any fitness level so this game really is for everybody. You can add hand weights for an even harder workout if you want. I definitely find myself out of breath and my heart rate pumping doing these workouts.The Kinect detection isn't flawless with this game but it's very, very good. Sometimes it doesn't recognize when I'm doing a move correctly but it's not a big deal. The game gives me credit for the calories burned and I still benefit from the excersize, whether I'm doing it "perfectly" or being detected perfectly or not. Speaking of calories, this game tracks the calories burned so you can get a real sense of accomplishment, and keep track if you are making a log of calories consumed and burned. I should mention you do need the full minimum of 6ft space in front of the Kinect to play this game.Not only is this the best fitness game out there (and I've tried several) it is really the only excersize regimine I've done that fits with my life. It is extremely convenient and fun which encourages sticking to it, unlike other routines. Goodbye inconvenient gyms, boring home treadmills, excersize games that don't work well, and goodbye to not getting the excersize I want and need. Finally, I can have it conveniently and fun.
summary: FINALLY a workout routine I can live with!

Title: N/A

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much from this, despite my high opinion of the kinect system overall.  But when it first fired up, "scanned" me, and showed me a very detailed representation of me, I was shocked.  Detail was impressive.  And the visual capture of movement was outstanding.  For anyone who hasn't seen it yet, don't think it's anything like the little "ghost" avatars you use in games.  This is detailed down to seeing zippers, collars, anything embossed on your clothes, etc...And when you're exercising, you begin to derezz (hello Tron fans!) if you step outside of the sensor's area.  So it is very easy to keep in place.This is NOT some high end thing for people looking for advanced exercises, so I'm not sure I understand why some of the people are taking stars away from it...  That's like complaining that the car I purchased can't fly at an altitude of 10,000 feet.  This isn't designed for that.  If you're that advanced, you're likely already using other tools or a real gym for your needs.  This is more towards people like me, with jobs that keep us sedentary far too much.  If you're out of shape and want to start getting back into shape, then this is a fantastic option.  Gives some motivation, far more enjoyable than just stepping on your stairmaster or elliptical trainer at home and watching the clock.  Will you get the same workout as you would at the gym?  Obviously not.  But it is a great tool to start getting yourself in that direction.controls are the same as most of the kinect things, my complaint on that score is to choose something you hold your hand to that button, which then opens ANOTHER button you have to move to and hold to select.  Would've preferred just the first button as the one to hold.  Seems a needless step to me.  But other than that little annoyance, it's very simple.  You also use your feet to select things, such as the number of people participating in an activity.The representation of you that it shows is very near real time, so the processing it is doing is impressive.  Which makes it feasible to mimic the trainer on screen, and to stay in sync with them.Advanced exercisers may find it a bit lacking physically, but enjoyable visually or for a change of pace.  You can still get your heart going, and add weights to help get more out of it.For someone like me who wants to get more fit after quitting smoking and sitting at a desk for too long, it's a great tool.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Lisa Shea "be the change you wish to see in t...
reviewText: Your Shape Fitness Evolved Kinect is an exercise program created with the XBox 360 Kinect system. That means you need no controllers or wands or buttons - you just do the exercises, and the camera knows what you are doing!We currently have both this game and the Biggest Loser game. This Your Shape game is MUCH easier to use. The controls on the Biggest Loser (entering your weight, entering your daily calories burned outside the game, etc) is an absolute royal pain. Here they have a superb system worked out. You move your hand to see what your choices are, then hold to confirm the one you're on. That lets you preview your options and then be sure before you go on to a new screen.Your Shape offers training, classes, and games. I always start with the games :) They are quite fun! You're punching boxes in various places, or balancing blocks over your head, or hula-hooping or playing foot-moving activities. The boxes are my favorite. My only complaint is that they should last longer and have more levels.The classes are in two categories - cardio-boxing classes and "zen" (a mix of tai-chi and yoga). Both are enjoyable. I had fun doing the boxing at the beginning, and then winding down with the zen. They backgrounds are appropriate for each.For the main training program, you first do a fitness test to determine your level, and then it gives you suggestions about programs to do. You can choose a male or female trainer. You do squats, lunges, or whatever other activities help you move towards your goals.They did a great job balancing the intros. There is enough of a demo to make sure you know what is going on, but you're not trapped doing a demo for eons.The game isn't perfect - this is of course their "first round" at a Kinect game and it shows. In some of the scenarios they toss commands at you to do "upper cuts" or "hooks" without any explanation or demonstration. Sometimes there's no vocal prompts at all so you have to assume you'll miss the first move or two while you figure out what is going on. In some scenarios like the skin-choosing there's no "back" option so you have to keep cycling forward through all the choices to loop around to the one you want. There's no way to change your profile without starting from the beginning and altering everything including your photo.Also, I do give the Biggest Loser kudos for being better with the feedback. In the Biggest Loser they show you clearly what you're doing wrong so you can adjust your posture. Here they will occasionally do that, but mostly they just tell you "it's wrong" / "you're out of rhythm" and you have to wildly guess what they are upset about. Sometimes they say you're not matching the rhythm of the moves when really they want you to raise your arms higher or deepen your squat. It makes for some frustrating exchanges.However that all is minor next to the main issue - their tracking all gives you rewards for hitting milestones of 100 calories, 1000 calories, and so on. You can't set your own levels! What if I want to aim for 2000 calories a day as my daily workout amount? I have no way to set that. I also have no way to enter calories I did outside the game, to help track my progress. That all greatly reduces its usefulness in helping me meet my health goals.So yes I enjoy playing this a lot, and it will become a regular part of my weekly routine. But the next version they make needs some improvements before it gets a full five stars.Rating: 4/5 starsI purchased this game with my own money from a gaming store.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Louie the Italian Jew "Lou da Joo"
reviewText: I bought this title based on my opinion of a prior Ubisoft exercise game that I really enjoyed working out with.Gold's Gym Cardio Workoutis probably the best Wii exercise game that I've ever played. I bought this title based on the premise that Ubisoft makes great exercise games (Ubisoft please bring Gold's Gym Cardio Workout to the Kinect).Let me also add that,Red Steel 2andAssassin's Creed IIare two of the most over-hyped 4 and 5 star Ubisoft games that have great reviews that I've ever played (just my personal opinion, don't beat me up). Anyway, I took a gamble, and thought  this game could be another Ubisoft over-hyped game. I bought this title based on my opinion that Ubisoft made a great exercise game, and I was right!I did have a lot of problems at first with space requirements, so I bought a Kinect bracket and placed the sensor on top of my TV, and the problem of space went away. I mostly play the beginning level cardio boxing, which is based on short 5 or 10 minute workouts of punching and kicking. Every time you throw a punch or kick correctly, the on-screen display gives you a green circle that is then filled in, and a rewarding soft chime sound. You can either follow the on-screen character or follow the heads up display. After about 30 seconds or so, the game will tell you how much of a percentage was executed correctly (There are more challenging routines if you prefer, although the MOST challenging requires you buy add-on content).Afterward, I usually take a water break and play the gym games. The gym games are a lot of fun. I play the Virtual Blocks mostly which is punching and kicking across your body. At the higher levels a pendulum swings across, and you have to duck (squat). I also play the Stack em up game which is holding out your arms and acting like a balance. You have to catch the blocks are drop them in the pit that appears and disappear on either side. If you squat, the blocks come down faster and you receive more points(Your arms will feel the pain after about a couple of rounds of holding them straight out depending on your fitness level, and the squatting isn't easy). At the higher levels, burning blocks will drop and you have to extinguish the fire by raising your corresponding leg. Really fun and challenging.Overall, this game works very well with the Kinect, and is overall responsive without any lag. I haven't run into any issues regarding any of the programs mentioned above, although I have found tracking issues during the Zen (yoga) activities. Additionally, I would have liked to create my own workout as an option. Overall, I'd have to recommend this game for someone that would like to work out at home, and personally find this routine more motivating thanEA Sports Active 2, although EA has more options like creating your own workout and adding your own music. I personally switch up between the two. If I had to choose one though, I'd choose this one. Being able to edit workouts would make this the perfect title. Hopefully editing workouts for the next Your Shape,will be possible. Until then I will have to include lunges in workouts, which I'd rather just skip because I'm not in good enough shape to perform lunges correctly.

reviewText: I ownWii Fit Plus with Balance Board,ExerBeatandJillian Michaels Fitness Ultimatum 2010.  I just boughtXbox 360 4GB Console with Kinectand wanted to use it for my workouts.  From the looks of the internet videos, Your Shape looked like the most fun.After a week, all I can say is Your Shape is the best workout I've ever had in a video game.  As a matter of fact, it's even better than going to the classes at the gym.  It's more like having a good personal trainer.  I get hot and sweaty.  I breathe hard.  In fact, I've actually had to stop the game to catch my breath.This thing won't let me cheat.  It catches me every time I'm off.  I get sore the next day, because I bent lower and stepped wider.  It tracks my movements well.GAMES AND LESSONSThe mini-games are a nice break, but they are not as physically demanding as the exercises.  There, I can punch bricks, hula hoop, step on lights, etc.The fitness classes are lots of fun.  They have Zen, cardio boxing and other classes.  The more I play, the more classes I unlock.Personal Training is where I've been spending most of my time.  I can pick a focus like cardio or circuit training some other training regimen.  There are twelve sessions in each that can last up to 20 minutes.  When I come back each day, I do the next session.  The only thing I don't like is it doesn't remember the sessions if I switch say from one regimen to another.  I'd have to start all over with the first session.  This prevents me from sampling the different training regimens because I want to finish up all the sessions and not have to keep repeating the first one.The training sessions have a timer and the repetitions count down so I can look forward to the end.  Nice touch.When I'm done, the number of Calories I've burned for the day is displayed.  I don't see total time, though.FINAL THOUGHTSI've learned never to play Your Shape just before leaving for work because I need to shower afterwards!  For days like that, I use Wii Fit.  When I can afford to be exhausted, I use Your Shape.
summary: Like having my own personal trainer

reviewText: This game is okay at best,  the entry level cardio workouts are good for those who are just beginning, after about 2-3 workouts you will be ready to progress to advanced cardio.  I played this game for about 3 weeks straight for an 1 1/2 hours 3 times a week.  Most of the exercises are recognized by kinect and are really good, but a few like the cross ski are completely broken in that no matter how you match the instructor it never recognizes you doing the exercise right - this means you cant progress any further in the game.  I think another one was the side/back lunges that don't pickup right.So this leads to the problem, I'm on the advanced cardio and now am stuck because no matter how hard I try to mimic the cross ski it always gives me a 0% score so I cant ever pass that stage, so here I am continually doing the cross ski and power jog exercises over and over and can't continue on to any other exercise.  This just makes the game boring, I had to reset the save profile to start over again but within 3 exercise sessions I'm back to square one.Overall it really does provide a decent workout until you run into problems with exercises not picking up your movements right.The gym games and fitness classes seem useless as they dont keep your heart rate up and are very short.This game if baked for another few months in development would have really helped it.I do give it credit that you can navigate the game fully with your hands and do not need a controller ever.  But the limited exercises and the non recognition making the game stuck is unforgivable.

reviewText: honestly I hate working out. I hate going to the gym. I know I need to work out, I will not go to a gym, one I am too cheap to do that and two I am know I am too lazy to do it. reviewText: I really like Kinect Fitness.  My fitness level isn't great.  I'm  female and underweight, but I am really weak and need to tone up my muscles.  The work-outs are fun, and if they are too short for you, then you can always do multiple ones, one after another.  The gym games are really fun to play with other people, especially the hoola hoop one.  I also think it's cool that you can see a mini version of yourself on the screen while you work out.  The only problem with this game is that it sometimes has a hard time reading your movements.  For instance, it looked like I was doing the exact same thing the fitness instructor was, but it wouldn't always register.  That doesn't really bother me, though, because I'm getting the same work-out whether it realizes it or not, so it's not a big deal.  I would definitely recommend this game.
summary: Good work-out and lots of fun

Title: N/A

reviewText: I was concerned after all the complaints Ive heard about the Kinect not being precise, needing calibration all the time, plus all the space it requires.  I was more nervous when I saw a lot of complaints about the fitness games.  That the reps arent recognized, that the movements arent seen, or that or stops working all together.This games does not have any of those problems.  Its very accurate, I feel a bit strange actually seeing a rendered version of myself on the screen, but one can see exactly how precise it is.  Ive only tried 3 of the mini games.  The balance game, the block busting, boxing based game, and the hula hoop game.  I have to say that the balance game didnt offer me much of a workout, nor does it really test balance, but it is a game.  The other two games definitely offer a workout, especially if you are seriously trying for both speed and accuracy.I love the different modes the game offers, and the fact that there is plenty of downloadable content and Im sure more on the way.  I like the fact that you see yourself, not the avatar you set up.  This way, you see your form, you see how you truly look, and theres less confusion.The only thing that did confuse me was the first time I powered on the game and they are setting up the profile.  I was told to touch a blue block.  I kept reaching, but nothing happened.  Then, I stepped to the right and my arm went beyond the block, which caused a reaction.  This particular section was trying to explain why you need to stay inside the play zone, and if you go out, you wont be recognized.I have to say that I wouldnt suggest buying this game...well ANY game to satisfy a workout routine.  Aside from this, I get to the gym 3-5 days a week, do plenty of cardio and weight lifting, which really shows results.  If toning, weight loss, or true cardio training is what you want, then youll have to venture out for it.  This is just a nice addition to your normal routine.Id suggest this over the other games simply because of the wide variety of fitness options and because of how accurate it is.
